Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the section regarding "Holders of Record," which typically provides details about the ownership of the company's stock, crucial for understanding shareholder distribution and rights.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, there were approximately 7,305 and 1,757 stockholders of record of our Class A stock and Class C stock, respectively. Because many of our shares of Class A stock and Class C stock are held by brokers and other institutions on behalf of stockholders, we are unable to estimate the total number of stockholders represented by these record holders. As of December 31, 2023, there were approximately 59 stockholders of record of our Class B stock.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides numeric data on the number of stockholders of record for different classes of the company’s stock as of a certain date. This information is relevant for assessing the shareholder base and the potential influence of different stockholders on corporate governance.

Original_Content: Dividend Policy
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the company's "Dividend Policy," which is an important aspect of its financial strategy and shareholder returns. It indicates the company's approach to distributing profits to shareholders.

Original_Content: We have never declared or paid any cash dividend on our common or capital stock. The primary use of capital continues to be to invest for the long-term growth of the business. We regularly evaluate our cash and capital structure, including the size, pace, and form of capital return to stockholders.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the company's dividend policy, stating that it has not paid dividends historically and prioritizes long-term growth investments. This context is vital for investors interested in income versus growth strategies.

Original_Content: ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces a major section of the report focused on Management's Discussion and Analysis (MD&A) of the financial condition and results of operations, which is critical for understanding the company's financial health and strategic outlook.

Original_Content: Please read the following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations together with “Note about Forward-Looking Statements,” Part I, Item 1 "Business," Part I, Item 1A "Risk Factors," and our consolidated financial statements and related notes included under Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This segment instructs readers to consider the MD&A in conjunction with other sections of the report, emphasizing the interconnected nature of the financial statements, risk factors, and forward-looking statements.

Original_Content: The following section generally discusses 2023 results compared to 2022 results. Discussion of 2022 results compared to 2021 results to the extent not included in this report can be found in Item 7 of our 2022 Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk summarizes the focus of the upcoming analysis, which will compare financial results from 2023 to 2022, while also indicating that prior year comparisons can be found in the previous annual report, providing historical context for the analysis.

Original_Content: Understanding Alphabet’s Financial Results
Contextualized_Context: This title introduces the section that explains Alphabet's financial results, indicating that the following content will delve into the company's performance metrics and financial health in detail.

Original_Content: Alphabet is a collection of businesses — the largest of which is Google. We report Google in two segments, Google Services and Google Cloud; we also report all non-Google businesses collectively as Other Bets. For additional information on our segments, see Part I, Item 1 Business and Note 15 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk outlines Alphabet's business structure, identifying its main segments (Google Services and Google Cloud) and the categorization of non-Google businesses as Other Bets, providing a framework for understanding the company's diversified operations.

Original_Content: Trends in Our Business and Financial Effect
Contextualized_Context: This heading introduces a discussion about the long-term trends affecting Alphabet's business and financial outcomes, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of external factors influencing performance.

Original_Content: The following long-term trends have contributed to the results of our consolidated operations, and we anticipate that they will continue to affect our future results:
Contextualized_Context: This chunk indicates that the following points will detail specific long-term trends that have historically impacted Alphabet's operations and are expected to continue doing so, providing a roadmap for the analysis.

Original_Content: • Users' behaviors and advertising continue to shift online as the digital economy evolves.
Contextualized_Context: This point highlights a key trend of shifting consumer behavior toward online platforms, which has significant implications for Alphabet's advertising revenue and strategic positioning in the digital economy.

Original_Content: The continuing evolution of the online world has contributed to the growth of our business and our revenues since inception. We expect that this evolution will continue to benefit our business and our revenues, although at a slower pace than we have experienced historically, in particular after the outsized growth in our advertising revenues during the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, we face increasing competition for user engagement and advertisers, which may affect our revenues.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the impact of online evolution on Alphabet's growth, noting the importance of staying competitive amidst changing dynamics in user engagement and advertising, especially post-COVID-19 pandemic.

Original_Content: • Users continue to access our products and services using diverse devices and modalities, which allows for new advertising formats that may benefit our revenues but adversely affect our margins.
Contextualized_Context: This point discusses the diverse ways users access Alphabet's services and the implications for advertising strategies, indicating both opportunities for revenue growth and potential challenges to profit margins.

Original_Content: Our users are accessing our products and services via diverse devices and modalities, such as smartphones, wearables, connected TVs, and smart home devices, and want to be able to be connected no matter where they are or what they are doing. We are focused on expanding our products and services to stay in front of these trends in order to maintain and grow our business.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk further describes the importance of adapting to changing user behaviors and preferences across various devices, emphasizing Alphabet's commitment to evolving its product offerings to sustain and expand its market presence.

Original_Content: We benefit from advertising revenues generated from different channels, including mobile, and newer advertising formats. The margins from these channels and newer products have generally been lower than those from traditional desktop search. Additionally, as the market for a particular device type or modality matures, our advertising revenues may be affected. For example, changing dynamics within the global smartphone market, such as increased market saturation in developed countries, can affect our mobile advertising revenues.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses the sources of advertising revenue for Alphabet Inc. and highlights the challenges related to lower profit margins from mobile and newer advertising formats compared to traditional desktop search. It sets the stage for understanding how market dynamics, especially in the smartphone sector, can impact overall advertising revenue.

Original_Content: We expect TAC paid to our distribution partners and Google Network partners to increase as our revenues grow and TAC as a percentage of our advertising revenues ("TAC rate") to be affected by changes in device mix; geographic mix; partner agreement terms; partner mix; the percentage of queries channeled through paid access points; product mix; the relative revenue growth rates of advertising revenues from different channels; and revenue share terms.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the concept of Traffic Acquisition Cost (TAC) and its expected increase as Alphabet’s revenues grow. It introduces various factors that influence TAC, which is crucial for understanding the company's cost structure related to advertising revenue, and links to broader trends in revenue generation.

Original_Content: We expect these trends to continue to affect our revenues and put pressure on our margins.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk serves as a summary statement indicating that the trends discussed in the previous chunks will have ongoing implications for Alphabet’s revenue and profit margins. It reflects the interconnected nature of the factors affecting the company’s financial performance.

Original_Content: • As online advertising evolves, we continue to expand our product offerings, which may affect our monetization.
Contextualized_Context: Here, the discussion indicates the evolution of online advertising and Alphabet's response through expanding product offerings. This sets up a broader discussion on how these changes may impact revenue generation and monetization strategies in future sections.

Original_Content: As interactions between users and advertisers change, and as online user behavior evolves, we continue to expand our product offerings to serve these changing needs, which may affect our monetization. For example, revenues from ads on YouTube and Google Play monetize at a lower rate than our traditional search ads. We also expect to continue to incorporate AI innovations into our products, such as AI in Search, that could affect our monetization trends. When developing new products and services we generally focus first on user experience and then on monetization.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk details how changes in user interactions and behavior influence Alphabet's monetization strategies. It provides examples of specific platforms like YouTube and Google Play, which highlight the varying revenue rates and the integration of AI, illustrating the company’s strategic focus on user experience before monetization.

Original_Content: • As users in developing economies increasingly come online, our revenues from international markets continue to increase, and may require continued investments. In addition, movements in foreign exchange rates affect such revenues.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the importance of international markets in Alphabet's revenue strategy, particularly as more users from developing economies come online. It underscores the necessity for continued investment in these regions and highlights the impact of foreign exchange rates on revenues.

Original_Content: 29.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk appears to be an artifact or placeholder and does not contain substantive content.

Original_Content: The shift to online, as well as the advent of the multi-device world, has brought opportunities outside of the U.S., including in emerging markets, such as India. We continue to invest heavily and develop localized versions of our products and advertising programs relevant to our users in these markets. This has led to a trend of increased revenues from emerging markets. We expect that our results will continue to be affected by our performance in these markets, particularly as low-cost mobile devices become more available. This trend could affect our revenues as developing markets initially monetize at a lower rate than more mature markets.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses the growth of revenues from emerging markets, emphasizing localized product development. It reinforces the strategic importance of these markets and how initial monetization might be lower compared to more established markets.

Original_Content: International revenues represent a significant portion of our revenues and are subject to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates relative to the U.S. dollar. While we have a foreign exchange risk management program designed to reduce our exposure to these fluctuations, this program does not fully offset their effect on our revenues and earnings.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk highlights the significance of international revenues and the challenges posed by foreign exchange fluctuations. It emphasizes the complexity of managing revenues in a global context and the limitations of the company's risk management strategies.

Original_Content: • The revenues that we derive beyond advertising are increasing and may adversely affect our margins.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk indicates that revenues derived from non-advertising sources are increasing, suggesting a diversification of revenue streams. It prepares the reader for discussions on how this shift may influence overall profit margins.

Original_Content: Revenues from cloud, consumer subscriptions, platforms, and devices, which may have differing characteristics than our advertising revenues, have grown over time, and we expect this trend to continue as we focus on expanding our products and services. The margins on these revenues vary significantly and are generally lower than the margins on our advertising revenues. For example, sales of our devices adversely affect our consolidated margins due to pressures on pricing and higher cost of sales.
Contextualized_Context: Here, the focus is on the growth of alternative revenue sources, such as cloud and subscription services, while also warning about their generally lower margins compared to advertising revenues. This establishes a contrast between different revenue types and their financial implications.

Original_Content: • As we continue to serve our users and expand our businesses, we will invest heavily in operating and capital expenditures.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk indicates an ongoing commitment to significant investments in operational and capital expenditures, which is important for understanding the company’s growth strategy and resource allocation.

Original_Content: We continue to make significant research and development investments in areas of strategic focus as we seek to develop new, innovative offerings, improve our existing offerings, and rapidly and responsibly deploy AI across our businesses. We also expect to increase, relative to 2023, our investment in our technical infrastructure, including servers, network equipment, and data centers, to support the growth of our business and our long-term initiatives, in particular in support of AI products and services. In addition, acquisitions and strategic investments contribute to the breadth and depth of our offerings, expand our expertise in engineering and other functional areas, and build strong partnerships around strategic initiatives.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the nature of Alphabet's investments in research and development, technical infrastructure, and strategic partnerships. Original_Content: • We continue to face an evolving regulatory environment, and we are subject to claims, lawsuits, investigations, and other forms of potential legal liability, which could affect our business practices and financial results.

Original_Content: Changes in social, political, economic, tax, and regulatory conditions or in laws and policies governing a wide range of topics and related legal matters, including investigations, lawsuits, and regulatory actions, have resulted in fines and caused us to change our business practices. As these global trends continue, our cost of doing business may increase, our ability to pursue certain business models or offer certain products or services may be limited, and we may need to change our business practices to comply with evolving regulatory and legal matters. Examples include the antitrust complaints filed by the U.S. Department of Justice and a number of state Attorneys General; legislative proposals and pending litigation in the U.S., EU, and around the world that could diminish or eliminate safe harbor protection for websites and online platforms; and the Digital Markets Act and Digital Services Act in Europe and various legislative proposals in the U.S. focused on large technology platforms. For additional information, see Item 1A Risk Factors and Legal Matters in Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Part II, Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.

Original_Content: In January 2023, we announced a reduction of our workforce, and as a result we recorded employee severance and related charges of $2.1 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023. In addition, we are taking actions to optimize our global office space. As a result, exit charges recorded during the year ended December 31, 2023, were $1.8 billion. In addition to these exit charges, for the year ended December 31, 2023, we incurred $269 million in accelerated rent and accelerated depreciation. For additional information, see Note 8 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.

Original_Content: Google subscriptions, platforms, and devices revenues increased $1.0 billion from 2021 to 2022 primarily driven by growth in subscription and device revenues, partially offset by a decrease in platform revenues. The growth in subscriptions was largely for YouTube services, primarily due to an increase in paid subscribers. The growth in device revenues was primarily driven by increased sales of Pixel devices. The decrease in platform revenues was primarily due to Google Play, driven by the fee structure changes we announced in 2021 as well as a decrease in buyer spending. Original_Content: Use of Non-GAAP Constant Currency Information
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the section discussing the "Use of Non-GAAP Constant Currency Information." It indicates a focus on financial metrics that exclude the effects of currency volatility, highlighting the company's approach to financial reporting and performance evaluation.

Original_Content: International revenues, which represent a significant portion of our revenues, are generally transacted in multiple currencies and therefore are affected by fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk explains the significance of international revenues and their exposure to currency fluctuations. It sets the context for understanding the challenges and considerations in analyzing Alphabet Inc.'s financial results, particularly for global operations.

Original_Content: The effect of currency exchange rates on our business is an important factor in understanding period-to-period comparisons. We use non-GAAP constant currency revenues ("constant currency revenues") and non-GAAP percentage change in constant currency revenues ("percentage change in constant currency revenues") for financial and operational decision-making and as a means to evaluate period-to-period comparisons. We believe the presentation of results on a constant currency basis in addition to U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) results helps improve the ability to understand our performance, because it excludes the effects of foreign currency volatility that are not indicative of our core operating results.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the importance of constant currency revenues in providing a clearer picture of financial performance. It highlights the company's rationale for using non-GAAP measures, enhancing the reader's understanding of the financial narrative presented throughout the document.

Original_Content: Constant currency information compares results between periods as if exchange rates had remained constant period over period. We define constant currency revenues as revenues excluding the effect of foreign currency exchange rate movements ("FX Effect") as well as hedging activities, which are recognized at the consolidated level. We use constant currency revenues to determine the constant currency revenue percentage change on a year-on-year basis. Constant currency revenues are calculated by translating current period revenues using prior year comparable period exchange rates, as well as excluding any hedging effects realized in the current period.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk defines constant currency revenues and explains the methodology used for calculating them. It provides essential information for readers to comprehend how the company analyzes its revenues, especially in the context of currency fluctuations, which is critical for accurate financial assessment.

Original_Content: Constant currency revenue percentage change is calculated by determining the change in current period revenues over prior year comparable period revenues where current period foreign currency revenues are translated using prior year comparable period exchange rates and hedging effects are excluded from revenues of both periods.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk explains the methodology used to calculate the constant currency revenue percentage change, which is important for understanding how foreign currency exchange rates impact the financial performance of Alphabet Inc. It situates itself within the broader discussion of revenue reporting and financial metrics in the company's financial results.

Original_Content: These results should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, results reported in accordance with GAAP. Results on a constant currency basis, as we present them, may not be comparable to similarly titled measures used by other companies and are not a measure of performance presented in accordance with GAAP.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk emphasizes the importance of GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) in financial reporting and clarifies that the constant currency results are supplementary to GAAP results. It highlights the limitations of constant currency measures, positioning them within the overall framework of Alphabet Inc.'s financial disclosures.

Original_Content: Cost of revenues increased $7.1 billion from 2022 to 2023 due to an increase in other cost of revenues and TAC of $5.2 billion and $1.9 billion, respectively.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the increase in total cost of revenues from 2022 to 2023, giving insight into the factors driving these cost changes, which is crucial for evaluating the company's cost management strategies.

Original_Content: The increase in TAC from 2022 to 2023 was largely due to an increase in TAC paid to distribution partners, primarily driven by growth in revenues subject to TAC. The TAC rate decreased from 21.8% to 21.4% from 2022 to 2023 primarily due to a revenue mix shift from Google Network properties to Google Search & other properties. The TAC rate on Google Search & other revenues and the TAC rate on Google Network revenues were both substantially consistent from 2022 to 2023.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk details the reasons behind the increase in TAC from 2022 to 2023, providing context for understanding the company's relationships with distribution partners and the impact of revenue mix shifts on cost structures.

Original_Content: The increase in other cost of revenues from 2022 to 2023 was primarily due to increases in content acquisition costs, largely for YouTube, and compensation expenses, which included $479 million of charges related to employee severance associated with the reduction in our workforce. Additionally, other cost of revenues benefited from a reduction in depreciation expense due to the change in estimated useful lives of our servers and network equipment.

text:
Original_Content: R&D expenses increased $5.9 billion from 2022 to 2023 primarily driven by an increase in compensation expenses of $2.9 billion, $870 million in charges related to our office space optimization efforts, and an increase in depreciation expense of $722 million. The $2.9 billion increase in compensation expenses was largely the result of a 4% increase in average headcount, after adjusting for roles affected by the reduction in our workforce, and an increase in SBC expense. Additionally, the increase in compensation expenses included $848 million in employee severance charges associated with the reduction in our workforce. The $722 million increase in depreciation expense reflected an offsetting benefit of the change in the estimated useful lives of our servers and network equipment.
Contextualized_Context: This narrative explains the increase in R&D expenses from 2022 to 2023, providing detailed insights into the factors driving these changes. text:
Original_Content: In 2023, the Internal Revenue Services (IRS) issued a rule change allowing taxpayers to temporarily apply the regulations in effect prior to 2022 related to U.S. federal foreign tax credits, as well as a separate rule change with interim guidance on the capitalization and amortization of R&D expenses. A cumulative one-time adjustment applicable to the prior period for these tax rule changes was recorded in 2023.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk highlights the decrease in the effective tax rate, linking it to IRS rule changes, which is important for understanding the tax landscape and its effects on net income.

Original_Content: The effective tax rate decreased from 2022 to 2023, reflecting the effect of the two tax rule changes described above, particularly the change related to foreign tax credits. The effect of these tax rule changes was partially offset by changes in uncertain tax benefits and a decrease in the U.S. federal Foreign Derived Intangible Income tax deduction.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses international negotiations regarding tax policies and potential changes in future tax obligations, providing context for long-term planning and fiscal strategy of Alphabet Inc.

Original_Content: The OECD is coordinating negotiations among more than 140 countries with the goal of achieving consensus around substantial changes to international tax policies, including the implementation of a minimum global effective tax rate of 15%. While various countries have implemented the legislation as of January 1, 2024, we do not expect a resulting material change to our income tax provision for the 2024 fiscal year. As additional jurisdictions enact such legislation, we expect our effective tax rate and cash tax payments could increase in future years.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk concludes the tax discussion, indicating expectations for future tax implications based on international legislation, which is crucial for stakeholders assessing the company's financial outlook and potential liabilities.

Contextualized_Context: This heading indicates a detailed discussion about Alphabet Inc.'s cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities. This section is part of the broader analysis of the company's liquidity and financial resources, which are critical for funding operations and investments.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, we had $110.9 billion in cash, cash equivalents, and short-term marketable securities. Cash equivalents and marketable securities are comprised of time deposits, money market funds, highly liquid government bonds, corporate debt securities, mortgage-backed and asset-backed securities, and marketable equity securities.

Contextualized_Context: This section outlines the sources and uses of cash and related trends for Alphabet Inc. It provides essential insights into how the company manages its liquidity and capital structure, crucial for understanding its financial strategies and operations.

Original_Content: Our principal sources of liquidity are cash, cash equivalents, and marketable securities, as well as the cash flow that we generate from operations. The primary use of capital continues to be to invest for the long-term growth of the business. We regularly evaluate our cash and capital structure, including the size, pace, and form of capital return to stockholders.

text:
Original_Content: Cash Provided by Operating Activities
Contextualized_Context: This section begins a discussion on cash flows from operating activities, which are vital for assessing the company's core business performance and ability to generate cash from operations.

Original_Content: Our largest source of cash provided by operations are advertising revenues generated by Google Search & other properties, Google Network properties, and YouTube properties. In Google Services, we also generate cash through consumer subscriptions and the sale of apps and in-app purchases and devices. In Google Cloud we generate cash through consumption-based fees and subscriptions for infrastructure, platform, collaboration tools, and other cloud services.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk describes the primary sources of cash provided by operating activities, highlighting the significance of advertising revenues and other income sources for Alphabet Inc.'s financial stability and growth.

Original_Content: Our primary uses of cash from operating activities include payments to distribution and Google Network partners, to employees for compensation, and to content providers. Other uses of cash from operating activities include payments to suppliers for devices, to tax authorities for income taxes, and other general corporate expenditures.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk outlines the primary uses of cash from operating activities, detailing where the company allocates its cash resources. It provides insight into operational expenses and commitments essential for maintaining business operations.

Original_Content: Net cash provided by operating activities increased from 2022 to 2023 due to the increase in cash received from customers, partially offset by increases in cash paid for cost of revenues and operating expenses.
Contextualized_Context: This section discusses the change in net cash provided by operating activities from 2022 to 2023, indicating financial growth and operational efficiency while noting the factors that influenced cash flow.

Contextualized_Context: This heading signals the beginning of a section focusing on cash used in investing activities, which is crucial for understanding how the company allocates funds for growth and expansion.

Original_Content: Cash provided by investing activities consists primarily of maturities and sales of investments in marketable and non-marketable securities. Cash used in investing activities consists primarily of purchases of marketable and non- marketable securities, purchases of property and equipment, and payments for acquisitions.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk details what constitutes cash provided by investing activities, highlighting investment strategies and expenditures related to marketable and non-marketable securities, property, and acquisitions.

Original_Content: Net cash used in investing activities increased from 2022 to 2023 due to a decrease in maturities and sales of marketable securities, partially offset by a decrease in payments for acquisitions.

Cash used in financing activities consists primarily of repurchases of stock, net payments related to stock-based award activities, and repayments of debt.

Original_Content: During the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, we spent $31.5 billion and $32.3 billion on capital expenditures, respectively. We expect to increase, relative to 2023, our investment in our technical infrastructure, including servers, network equipment, and data centers, to support the growth of our business and our long-term initiatives, in particular in support of AI products and services. Depreciation of our property and equipment commences when the deployment of such assets are completed and are ready for our intended use. Land is not depreciated. For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, our depreciation on property and equipment were $13.5 billion and $11.9 billion, respectively.
Contextualized_Context: This section provides specific figures on capital expenditures for 2022 and 2023, along with expectations for future investments. It contextualizes the company's financial commitment to infrastructure, particularly in technology and AI, which is vital for understanding its growth trajectory.

Original_Content: Leases
Contextualized_Context: The title "Leases" introduces a discussion on Alphabet's leasing arrangements, an important aspect of its financial commitments and operational flexibility.

Original_Content: For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, we recognized total operating lease assets of $4.4 billion and $2.9 billion, respectively. As of December 31, 2023, the amount of total future lease payments under operating leases, which had a weighted average remaining lease term of eight years, was $17.7 billion, of which $3.2 billion is short- term. As of December 31, 2023, we have entered into leases that have not yet commenced with future short-term and long-term lease payments of $657 million and $3.3 billion, that are not yet recorded on our Consolidated Balance Sheets. These leases will commence between 2024 and 2026 with non-cancelable lease terms of one to 25 years.
Contextualized_Context: This sentence details the company's operating lease assets and future lease payment obligations, providing insight into its long-term financial commitments and operational strategies.

Original_Content: For the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, our operating lease expenses (including variable lease costs) were $3.7 billion and $4.5 billion, respectively. Finance lease costs were not material for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023. For additional information, see Note 4 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This section summarizes the operating lease expenses for the years mentioned, highlighting the company's financial obligations related to leasing. It is critical for understanding the impact of leases on overall financial performance.

Original_Content: Financing
Contextualized_Context: The title "Financing" indicates a section that will discuss how Alphabet manages its capital structure, including debt financing and other financial instruments.

Original_Content: We have a short-term debt financing program of up to $10.0 billion through the issuance of commercial paper. Net proceeds from this program are used for general corporate purposes. As of December 31, 2023, we had no commercial paper outstanding.
Contextualized_Context: This sentence describes Alphabet's short-term financing strategy through commercial paper, providing insights into how the company raises capital for operational needs. It reflects the company's financial management practices.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, we had $10.0 billion of revolving credit facilities, $4.0 billion expiring in April 2024 and $6.0 billion expiring in April 2028. The interest rates for all credit facilities are determined based on a formula using certain market rates, as well as our progress toward the achievement of certain sustainability goals. No amounts have been borrowed under the credit facilities.
Contextualized_Context: This section explains the company's revolving credit facilities, detailing their amounts, expiration dates, and interest rate determination. It provides context for Alphabet's liquidity management and financial flexibility.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, we had senior unsecured notes outstanding with a total carrying value of $12.9 billion with short-term and long-term future interest payments of $214 million and $3.6 billion, respectively. For additional information, see Note 6 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides details about Alphabet Inc.'s financial obligations, specifically regarding senior unsecured notes as of December 31, 2023. It highlights the carrying value of these notes and future interest payments, indicating the company's debt situation. This information is relevant to investors and stakeholders assessing the company's financial health and capital structure.

Original_Content: We primarily utilize contract manufacturers for the assembly of our servers used in our technical infrastructure and devices we sell. We have agreements where we may purchase components directly from suppliers and then supply these components to contract manufacturers for use in the assembly of the servers and devices. Certain of these arrangements result in a portion of the cash received from and paid to the contract manufacturers to be presented as financing activities in the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses Alphabet Inc.'s reliance on contract manufacturers for assembling servers and devices, which is crucial for understanding the company's supply chain and operational strategy. Original_Content: European Commission Fines
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the topic of fines imposed by the European Commission on Google for competition law infringements. It sets the stage for understanding the regulatory challenges faced by the company, which is important for stakeholders concerned with compliance and legal risks.

Original_Content: In 2017, 2018 and 2019, the EC announced decisions that certain actions taken by Google infringed European competition law and imposed fines of €2.4 billion ($2.7 billion as of June 27, 2017), €4.3 billion ($5.1 billion as of June 30, 2018), and €1.5 billion ($1.7 billion as of March 20, 2019), respectively. On September 14, 2022, the General Court reduced the 2018 fine from €4.3 billion to €4.1 billion. We subsequently filed an appeal to the European Court of Justice.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk details the specific fines levied against Google by the European Commission in various years. It provides historical context and quantifies the financial impact of these legal actions, which is crucial for assessing the company's legal liabilities.

Original_Content: While each EC decision is under appeal, we included the fines in accrued expenses and other current liabilities on our Consolidated Balance Sheets as we provided bank guarantees (in lieu of a cash payment) for the fines. For additional information, see Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk explains the accounting treatment of the fines incurred by Alphabet Inc. while they are under appeal, indicating how these liabilities are reflected in the company's financial statements. This information is relevant for understanding the company's risk management and financial reporting practices.

Original_Content: Taxes
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the section on taxes, indicating a shift to discussing the company's tax obligations and liabilities, which are central to understanding its financial condition.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, we had income taxes payable of $4.2 billion, of which $2.1 billion was short-term, related to a one-time transition tax payable incurred as a result of the U.S. Tax Cuts and Jobs Act ("Tax Act"). As permitted by the Tax Act, we will pay the transition tax in annual interest-free installments through 2025. We also have long-term taxes payable of $6.3 billion primarily related to uncertain tax positions as of December 31, 2023.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk outlines the company's income taxes payable as of December 31, 2023, including details about short-term and long-term liabilities related to the U.S. Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. This information is significant for stakeholders evaluating the company's tax strategy and financial obligations.

Original_Content: Purchase Commitments and Other Contractual Obligations
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the topic of purchase commitments and contractual obligations, indicating a focus on the company's future financial commitments and operational planning.

Original_Content: As of December 31, 2023, we had material purchase commitments and other contractual obligations of $45.9 billion, of which $31.6 billion was short-term. These amounts primarily consist of purchase orders for certain technical infrastructure as well as the non-cancelable portion or the minimum cancellation fee in certain agreements related to commitments to purchase licenses, including content licenses, inventory and network capacity. For those agreements with variable terms, we do not estimate the non-cancelable obligation beyond any minimum quantities and/or pricing as of December 31, 2023. In certain instances, the amount of our contractual obligations may change based on the expected timing of order fulfillment from our suppliers. For more information related to our content licenses, see Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides specific figures related to Alphabet Inc.'s purchase commitments and contractual obligations as of December 31, 2023, detailing amounts and their nature. This information is critical for evaluating the company's future cash flow requirements and operational commitments.

Original_Content: In addition, we regularly enter into multi-year, non-cancellable agreements to purchase renewable energy and energy attributes, such as renewable energy certificates. These agreements do not include a minimum dollar commitment. The amounts to be paid under these agreements are based on the actual volumes to be generated and are not readily determinable.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses Alphabet Inc.'s agreements related to renewable energy purchases, which highlights the company's commitment to sustainability and environmental responsibility. It indicates that these obligations are variable and not easily quantifiable, providing insight into future financial planning related to sustainability initiatives.

Original_Content: Critical Accounting Estimates
Contextualized_Context: This section introduces the topic of critical accounting estimates, which are essential for understanding the financial statements of Alphabet Inc. It highlights the importance of estimates and assumptions in financial reporting and sets the stage for a detailed discussion of specific accounting estimates made by the company.

Original_Content: We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with GAAP. In doing so, we have to make estimates and assumptions. Our critical accounting estimates are those estimates that involve a significant level of uncertainty at the time the estimate was made, and changes in them have had or are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our financial condition or results of operations. Accordingly, actual results could differ materially from our estimates. We base our estimates on past experience and other assumptions that we believe are reasonable under the circumstances, and we evaluate these estimates on an ongoing basis. We have reviewed our critical accounting estimates with the Audit and Compliance Committee of our Board of Directors.
Contextualized_Context: This paragraph elaborates on how Alphabet Inc. prepares its consolidated financial statements in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). It emphasizes the uncertainty involved in accounting estimates and their potential impact on the company's financial condition and results. This chunk provides insight into the process of financial reporting and the inherent challenges faced by management.

Original_Content: For a summary of significant accounting policies and the effect on our financial statements, see Note 1 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This statement directs readers to additional information regarding significant accounting policies in the notes section of the financial statements. It serves as a cross-reference for readers who want to delve deeper into the specific accounting methods and their implications for the financial statements.

Original_Content: Fair Value Measurements of Non-Marketable Equity Securities
Contextualized_Context: This section introduces the topic of fair value measurements for non-marketable equity securities. It indicates that the following paragraphs will discuss how these investments are evaluated and reported, which is crucial for understanding Alphabet Inc.'s investment portfolio.

Original_Content: We measure certain financial instruments at fair value on a nonrecurring basis, consisting primarily of our non- marketable equity securities. These investments are accounted for under the measurement alternative method ("the measurement alternative") and are measured at cost, less impairment, subject to upward and downward adjustments resulting from observable price changes for identical or similar investments of the same issuer. These adjustments require quantitative assessments of the fair value of our securities, which may require the use of unobservable inputs. Adjustments are determined primarily based on a market approach as of the transaction date and involve the use of estimates using the best information available, which may include cash flow projections or other available market data.
Contextualized_Context: Here, the document explains the accounting treatment applied to non-marketable equity securities measured at fair value. It discusses the use of the measurement alternative method and the factors that influence adjustments to the fair value of these securities. This information is important for understanding the complexities involved in valuing investments.

Original_Content: Non-marketable equity securities are also evaluated for impairment, based on qualitative factors including the companies' financial and liquidity position and access to capital resources, among others. When indicators of impairment exist, we prepare quantitative measurements of the fair value of our equity investments using a market approach or an income approach, which requires judgment and the use of unobservable inputs, including discount rates, investee revenues and costs, and comparable market data of private and public companies, among others.
Contextualized_Context: This segment continues the discussion on non-marketable equity securities, focusing on the evaluation for impairment. It outlines the qualitative and quantitative factors that management considers, which adds depth to the understanding of risk assessment in the company's investment strategy.

Original_Content: 43.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk appears to be a placeholder or a part of the document's formatting, without substantive content.

Original_Content: Table of Contents
Contextualized_Context: Similar to Chunk 7, this section is likely part of the document's structure, specifically the table of contents, which organizes the sections of the report.

Original_Content: Alphabet Inc.
Contextualized_Context: This is a header indicating the subject of the document, specifically related to Alphabet Inc., which informs the reader about the overall content and focus of the report.

Original_Content: When the quantitative remeasurements of fair value indicate an impairment exists, we write down the investment to its current fair value.
Contextualized_Context: This statement describes the company's approach to recording impairments for investments when fair value assessments indicate a decline. It is relevant for understanding how Alphabet Inc. manages its investment portfolio and acknowledges potential losses.

Original_Content: We also have compensation arrangements with payouts based on realized returns from certain investments, i.e. performance fees. We record compensation expense based on the estimated payouts on an ongoing basis, which may result in expense recognized before investment returns are realized and compensation is paid and may require the use of unobservable inputs.
Contextualized_Context: This section addresses compensation arrangements tied to investment performance. It explains how such arrangements impact financial reporting and the need for estimates based on anticipated returns, which provides insight into the company's compensation strategy and financial planning.

Original_Content: Property and Equipment
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the topic of property and equipment, indicating that the following section will discuss the assessment of useful lives and related accounting practices, which are vital for understanding the company's capital expenditures.

Original_Content: We assess the reasonableness of the useful lives of our property and equipment periodically as well as when other changes occur, such as when there are changes to ongoing business operations, changes in the planned use and utilization of assets, or technological advancements, that could indicate a change in the period over which we expect to benefit from the assets.
Contextualized_Context: This paragraph details the company's evaluation process for determining the useful lives of property and equipment. It emphasizes the importance of regular assessments and their impact on financial statements, helping readers understand how depreciation is recorded.

Original_Content: Income Taxes
Contextualized_Context: This section introduces the topic of income taxes, indicating that the subsequent discussion will cover the company's tax obligations and accounting practices related to taxes.

Original_Content: We are subject to income taxes in the U.S. and foreign jurisdictions. Significant judgment is required in evaluating our uncertain tax positions and determining our provision for income taxes.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the complexities involved in evaluating uncertain tax positions and determining tax provisions. It highlights the judgment required in this area, which is critical for understanding the company's financial liabilities.

Original_Content: Recording an uncertain tax position involves various qualitative considerations, including evaluation of comparable and resolved tax exposures, applicability of tax laws, and likelihood of settlement. We evaluate uncertain tax positions periodically, considering changes in facts and circumstances, such as new regulations or recent judicial opinions, as well as the status of audit activities by taxing authorities. Although we believe we have adequately reserved for our uncertain tax positions, no assurance can be given that the final tax outcome of these matters will not be different. To the extent that the final tax outcome of these matters is different than the amounts recorded, such differences will affect the provision for income taxes and the effective tax rate in the period in which such determination is made.
Contextualized_Context: Here, the document explains how uncertain tax positions are recorded and the qualitative factors considered in their evaluation. This adds depth to the discussion on tax accounting and the potential implications for the company's financial statements.

Original_Content: The provision for income taxes includes the effect of reserve provisions and changes to reserves as well as the related net interest and penalties. In addition, we are subject to the continuous examination of our income tax returns by the IRS and other tax authorities which may assert assessments against us. We regularly assess the likelihood of adverse outcomes resulting from these examinations and assessments to determine the adequacy of our provision for income taxes.
Contextualized_Context: This section continues the discussion of income tax provisions, detailing the effects of reserve provisions and external examinations on the company's tax liabilities. It reinforces the importance of thorough tax compliance and reporting.

Original_Content: Loss Contingencies
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the topic of loss contingencies, indicating that the subsequent content will discuss the legal and regulatory challenges faced by Alphabet Inc., which is essential for understanding potential liabilities.

Original_Content: We are regularly subject to claims, lawsuits, regulatory and government investigations, other proceedings, and consent orders involving competition, intellectual property, privacy, data security, tax and related compliance, labor and employment, commercial disputes, content generated by our users, goods and services offered by advertisers or publishers using our platforms, personal injury consumer protection, and other matters. Certain of these matters include speculative claims for substantial or indeterminate amounts of damages. We record a liability when we believe that it is probable that a loss has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated. If we determine that a loss is reasonably possible and the loss or range of loss can be estimated, we disclose the possible loss in Note 10 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This paragraph provides details on various claims and lawsuits that Alphabet Inc. faces, emphasizing the company's approach to recording liabilities for these contingencies. It is important for understanding the risks and uncertainties related to ongoing legal matters.

Original_Content: We evaluate, on a regular basis, developments in our legal matters that could affect the amount of liability that has been previously accrued, and the matters and related reasonably possible losses disclosed, and make adjustments and changes to our disclosures. Significant judgment is required to determine both the likelihood and the estimated amount of a loss related to such matters. Until the final resolution of such matters, there may be an exposure to loss in excess of the amount recorded, and such amounts could be material.
Contextualized_Context: This section elaborates on the evaluation process for legal matters and how the company assesses potential losses. It underscores the significance of management judgment in determining legal liabilities, which is crucial for stakeholders assessing the company's risk exposure.

Original_Content: Change in Accounting Estimate
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the section on accounting estimates, indicating a discussion regarding changes in accounting estimates that have implications for financial reporting.

Original_Content: In January 2023, we completed an assessment of the useful lives of our servers and network equipment resulting in a change in the estimated useful life of our servers and certain network equipment to six years. This change in accounting estimate was effective beginning fiscal year 2023. For additional information, see Note 1 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8 of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the specific change in accounting estimate regarding the useful lives of servers and network equipment, highlighting a significant update that affects the fiscal year 2023 financials. It also refers the reader to additional information in the notes to the consolidated financial statements, emphasizing its importance.

Original_Content: ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK
Contextualized_Context: This chunk designates the beginning of a section dedicated to market risks, indicating that the following content will address quantitative and qualitative disclosures about various market risks faced by the company.

Original_Content: We are exposed to financial market risks, including changes in foreign currency exchange rates, interest rates, and equity investment risks.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides a summary of the types of financial market risks Alphabet Inc. is exposed to, setting the stage for more detailed discussions about each risk type in the subsequent sections.

Original_Content: Foreign Currency Exchange Risk
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the specific risk of foreign currency exchange, indicating that the following content will delve into how fluctuations in currency values affect the company's financial condition.

Original_Content: We transact business globally in multiple currencies. International revenues, as well as costs and expenses denominated in foreign currencies, expose us to the risk of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates against the U.S. dollar. As discussed below, we enter into derivative instruments to hedge foreign currency risk. Principal currencies hedged included the Australian dollar, British pound, Canadian dollar, Euro, and Japanese yen. For the purpose of analyzing foreign currency exchange risk, we considered the historical trends in foreign currency exchange rates and determined that it was reasonably possible that adverse changes in exchange rates of 10% could be experienced.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk explains the company's global operations and the resulting exposure to foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, detailing the measures taken to hedge this risk and outlining the currencies involved.

Original_Content: We use foreign currency forward and option contracts to offset the foreign exchange risk on assets and liabilities denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the subsidiary. These forward and option contracts reduce, but do not entirely eliminate, the effect of foreign currency exchange rate movements on our assets and liabilities. The foreign currency gains and losses on these assets and liabilities are recorded in OI&E, which are offset by the gains and losses on the forward and option contracts.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses the mechanisms used to mitigate foreign currency exchange risk, specifically through the use of forward and option contracts, and explains how these hedging strategies are accounted for in financial statements.

Original_Content: If an adverse 10% foreign currency exchange rate change was applied to total monetary assets, liabilities, and commitments denominated in currencies other than the functional currencies at the balance sheet date, it would have resulted in an adverse effect on income before income taxes of approximately $136 million and $503 million as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, respectively, after consideration of the effect of foreign exchange contracts in place for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk quantifies the potential financial impact of adverse foreign currency exchange rate changes on income before taxes, providing specific figures for the years 2022 and 2023, which underscores the importance of currency risk management.

Original_Content: We use foreign currency forward and option contracts, including collars (an option strategy comprised of a combination of purchased and written options) to protect forecasted U.S. dollar-equivalent earnings from changes in foreign currency exchange rates. When the U.S. dollar strengthens, gains from foreign currency forward and option contacts reduce the foreign currency losses related to our earnings. When the U.S. dollar weakens, losses from foreign currency forward and option contracts offset the foreign currency gains related to our earnings. These hedging contracts reduce, but do not entirely eliminate, the effect of foreign currency exchange rate movements. We designate these contracts as cash flow hedges for accounting purposes. We reflect the gains or losses of foreign currency spot rate changes as a component of accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI) and subsequently reclassify them into revenues to offset the hedged exposures as they occur.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk details additional hedging strategies, including the use of collars, and how these strategies are designated as cash flow hedges, which ties back to reporting practices and the management of earnings.

Original_Content: If the U.S. dollar weakened by 10% as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, the amount recorded in AOCI related to our cash flow hedges before tax effect would have been approximately $1.3 billion and $1.5 billion lower as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, respectively. The change in the value recorded in AOCI would be expected to offset a corresponding foreign currency change in forecasted hedged revenues when recognized.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides a hypothetical scenario to illustrate the potential impact of a weakened U.S. dollar on the company’s accumulated other comprehensive income (AOCI), demonstrating the financial implications of currency hedging strategies.

Original_Content: We use foreign exchange forward contracts designated as net investment hedges to hedge the foreign currency risks related to investment in foreign subsidiaries. These forward contracts serve to offset the foreign currency translation risk from our foreign operations.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the concept of net investment hedges, explaining how the company manages foreign currency risks associated with investments in foreign subsidiaries.

Original_Content: If the U.S. dollar weakened by 10%, the amount recorded in cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) within AOCI related to our net investment hedges before tax effect would have been approximately $903 million and $946 million lower as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, respectively. The change in value recorded in CTA would be expected to offset a corresponding foreign currency translation gain or loss from our investment in foreign subsidiaries.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk quantifies the potential impact of currency fluctuations on the cumulative translation adjustment (CTA) related to net investment hedges, further illustrating the financial risks involved in international operations.

Original_Content: Interest Rate Risk
Contextualized_Context: This chunk marks the beginning of a discussion on interest rate risk, indicating a shift in focus from currency risks to the risks associated with fluctuations in interest rates.

Original_Content: Our Corporate Treasury investment strategy is to achieve a return that will allow us to preserve capital and maintain liquidity. We invest primarily in debt securities, including government bonds, corporate debt securities, mortgage-backed and asset-backed securities, money market and other funds, time deposits, and interest rate derivatives. By policy, we limit the amount of credit exposure to any one issuer. Our investments in both fixed rate and floating rate interest earning securities carry a degree of interest rate risk. Fixed rate securities may have their fair market value adversely affected due to a rise in interest rates, while floating rate securities may produce less income than predicted if interest rates fall. Unrealized gains or losses on our marketable debt securities are primarily due to interest rate fluctuations as compared to interest rates at the time of purchase. For certain fixed and variable rate debt securities, we have elected the fair value option for which changes in fair value are recorded in OI&E. We measure securities for which we have not elected the fair value option at fair value with gains and losses recorded in AOCI until the securities are sold, less any expected credit losses.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk outlines Alphabet Inc.’s Corporate Treasury investment strategy, explaining the types of securities in which it invests and the associated risks, thereby providing insights into the company's financial management practices.

Original_Content: 45.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk appears to be another page number or reference marker, indicating a transition or separation in the document's content.

Original_Content: Table of Contents
Contextualized_Context: This chunk indicates another instance of the table of contents, reinforcing its navigational role within the document.

Original_Content: Alphabet Inc.
Contextualized_Context: Similar to Chunk 5, this chunk serves as a header, reiterating the document's identity and relevance to Alphabet Inc.

Original_Content: We use value-at-risk (VaR) analysis to determine the potential effect of fluctuations in interest rates on the value of our marketable debt security portfolio. The VaR is the expected loss in fair value, for a given confidence interval, for our investment portfolio due to adverse movements in interest rates. We use a variance/covariance VaR model with 95% confidence interval. The estimated one-day loss in fair value of marketable debt securities as of December 31, 2022 and 2023 are shown below (in millions):
Contextualized_Context: This chunk discusses the use of value-at-risk (VaR) analysis, a financial risk management tool that Alphabet Inc. employs to assess the potential impact of interest rate fluctuations on its marketable debt security portfolio. This content is part of the broader section on market risks, specifically focusing on interest rate risk, which is crucial for investors and analysts reviewing the company's financial stability and investment strategies.

This data supports the information presented in Chunk 1 and is essential for understanding the risk exposure in Alphabet Inc.'s investment portfolio, as it quantifies the potential financial impact of interest rate changes.

text:
Original_Content: Actual future gains and losses associated with our marketable debt security portfolio may differ materially from the sensitivity analyses performed as of December 31, 2022 and 2023 due to the inherent limitations associated with predicting the timing and amount of changes in interest rates and our actual exposures and positions. VaR analysis is not intended to represent actual losses but is used as a risk estimation.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk highlights the limitations of the VaR analysis mentioned in Chunk 1, emphasizing that actual future gains and losses may differ significantly from the estimates due to the unpredictable nature of interest rates. This disclaimer is important for stakeholders to recognize the inherent uncertainties in financial forecasting and risk assessment.

Original_Content: Equity Investment Risk
Contextualized_Context: This chunk introduces the topic of equity investment risk, signaling a shift from interest rate risk to another facet of market risk that Alphabet Inc. faces. It sets the stage for a more detailed examination of the risks associated with the company’s equity securities, both marketable and non-marketable.

Original_Content: Our marketable and non-marketable equity securities are subject to a wide variety of market-related risks that could substantially reduce or increase the fair value of our holdings.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk elaborates on the nature of equity investment risks that Alphabet Inc. is exposed to, indicating that both marketable and non-marketable equity securities can experience significant fluctuations in value. This information is important for investors and analysts as it outlines the potential volatility in Alphabet's investment portfolio.

Original_Content: Our marketable equity securities are publicly traded stocks or funds and our non-marketable equity securities are investments in privately held companies, some of which are in the startup or development stages.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk distinguishes between marketable and non-marketable equity securities held by Alphabet Inc., explaining that marketable securities are publicly traded while non-marketable securities are investments in private companies. This differentiation is crucial for understanding the types of investments that contribute to the company’s overall financial risk.

Original_Content: We record marketable equity securities not accounted for under the equity method at fair value based on readily determinable market values, of which publicly traded stocks and mutual funds are subject to market price volatility, and represent $5.2 billion and $6.0 billion of our investments as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, respectively. A hypothetical adverse price change of 10% on our December 31, 2023 balance would decrease the fair value of marketable equity securities by $597 million. From time to time, we may enter into derivatives to hedge the market price risk on certain of our marketable equity securities.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk provides numerical data on the fair value of Alphabet Inc.'s marketable equity securities as of December 31 for the years 2022 and 2023. It also discusses the potential impact of a hypothetical adverse price change on these investments. This information is critical for assessing the company's exposure to market price volatility and overall investment strategy.

Original_Content: Our non-marketable equity securities not accounted for under the equity method are adjusted to fair value for observable transactions for identical or similar investments of the same issuer or impairment (referred to as the measurement alternative). The fair value measured at the time of the observable transaction is not necessarily an indication of the current fair value as of the balance sheet date. These investments, especially those that are in the early stages, are inherently risky because the technologies or products these companies have under development are typically in the early phases and may never materialize, and they may experience a decline in financial condition, which could result in a loss of a substantial part of our investment in these companies. Valuations of our equity investments in private companies are inherently more complex due to the lack of readily available market data and observable transactions at lower valuations could result in significant losses. In addition, global economic conditions could result in additional volatility. The success of our investment in any private company is also typically dependent on the likelihood of our ability to realize appreciation in the value of investments through liquidity events such as public offerings, acquisitions, private sales or other market events. Changes in the valuation of non-marketable equity securities may not directly correlate with changes in valuation of marketable equity securities. As of December 31, 2022 and 2023, the carrying value of our non-marketable equity securities, which were accounted for under the measurement alternative, was $28.5 billion and $28.8 billion, respectively.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk addresses the valuation and risk assessment of non-marketable equity securities, including the complexities involved in their valuation and the risks associated with investing in early-stage companies. It highlights the challenges Alphabet Inc. faces in managing these investments, which is essential for understanding the company's financial position and risks.

Original_Content: The carrying values of our equity method investments, which totaled approximately $1.7 billion as of December 31, 2022 and 2023, generally do not fluctuate based on market price changes. However, these investments could be impaired if the carrying value exceeds the fair value and is not expected to recover.

It provides insight into how Alphabet Inc. accounts for these investments and the potential risks associated with their valuation, which is relevant for evaluating the company’s financial health.

Original_Content: 47.
Contextualized_Context: This chunk is another placeholder and does not contain content relevant to understanding the financial report. It serves as a separator or a reference marker in the document.

Contextualized_Context: This chunk is yet another placeholder indicating the presence of a table of contents, similar to Chunk 12, reinforcing the navigational structure of the document.
